The department is the key to the University, we will
learn today while sifting through pages of verbiage from
the summer governance committee. And just how do
Hopkins departments work? They debate substantive
conflicts in terms of procedure and mask their debates
in secrecy.

Social Relations department. Unlike other courses
which are automatically approved by the chairman, the
department saw fit to review Dr. Chester Wickwire's
request to add two more courses to its paultry offerings
this semester. Meeting in privacy, without even the
courtesy to allow Dr. Wickwire to defend his program
(protocol restricts "part-time lecturers" from such
deliberations), they concluded the courses are inappropriate.
Wickwire was notified in writing of the decision
yesterday without explanation. When the News-Letter
tried to find out what had happened, the department
chairman refused to comment, saying he will only
answer written inquiries.
So an inkling of what happened to the courses has been
effectively stifled and with that, the 150 students who
expressed interest in the two rejected courses have been
cheated.

professors exercise, exclusively running "their"
departments without any attempt to garner junior
faculty or student opinion.

Defending Governance
By T. CHRISTOPHER BEACH.
The Summer Goverance Committee has
submitted to the Dean of the Faculty of Arts
and Sciences a report that recommends a
new system of governance for this division.
Copies of the report are now being printed
and within a few days will be returned and
distributed to all members of the division.
The committee's conception of how the
division has previously been governed is well
stated in the introductory chapter of the
report."An almost universal theme, running
alike through administration, faculty, and
students, was the perilously high level of
frustration over how and where to get things
done. Individual grievances and suggestions
have not been acted upon or even answered.
"Academic and nonacademic programs
and policies have emerged full grown, like
Botticelli's Venus, from the depths of administrative silence." That silence has
pervaded all levels of this division, from the
Student Council's administering of its affairs
to the "Administration's" administering of
everyone' affairs.
The committee did not seek, however, to
address its report to specific issues raised or
specific decisions made in the past two or
three years. Rather, the attempt was to
propose a new system that clearly defines
where an individual issue may be discussed
and where a decision made. '
The purpose of establishing such a
system is twofold: (1) to guarantee that an
individual's opinion on a specific subject
would be heard at a point where a decision
could be affected and (2) to guarantee that
the thought behind his opinion would be
answered, if not acted upon.
Right to Advise
In the report, the above guarantees are
termed "the right to advise" and the right to
hold accountable those who are advised." In
practice, the guarantees mean that before
an administrator makes a decision, he must
inform those groups to be affected by the
decision and seek either their advice or the
advice of a duly constituted body that
represents them. If such advance is refected
of modified at the time of the decision, the
administrator must explain his decision if
the advisory body, or group, so requests.
Because Woody Bennett and .Harry
Singleton, two of the undergraduate
members of the committee, have not signed
the majority report and have explained
themselves in two separate minority
reports. I would like to explain why I, the
third undergraduate, have endorsed the
recommendations of the majority report.
Flexible System
If put into effect, the recommended
system can be amended so that parts of it

with which I disagree can be reconsidered
and perhaps changed. If put into effect, the
recommended system will permit any individual or group of individuals who have
raised a controversial issue to know why
they have been accepted or rejected.
More specifically, if the Arts and Sciences
Representative Council is established, the
undergraduates, graduate students,
research staff and faculty will finally have a
chance to cooperate and, as a single group,
advise the Dean. Although some students
argue that advisory power is no power, I
can't agree. As stated in its constitution, the
Academic Council had only advisory
power; yet, the power -Mat our faculty
generates through its Council is as great as
the faculty power in any other university in
the country.
Department Guidelines
Further, the departmental guidelines that
have been recommended offer an even more
significant change in governance. If adopted
and followed, these guidelines offer the
student a much greater chance to determine
the course of his education. As, such the
guidelines are easily the most important
proposal.
At the present moment academic and nonacademic issues are pressing for resolution.
Already, controversy over the issues of APL
and ROTC has begun again. Already, Dean
Code of Conduct is being
Benton's
challenged. These and other issues require
extensive discussion and major dicisions of
policy. If the discussion is to be 'reasonable
and the decisions responsible, the proposed
system of governance should be accepted by
all members of the division.
Best Alternative
Our choice is either to accept or reject the
proposals. If we accept them, we know
what the means are for effecting' student
voice. If we reject them we have either no
means, or what is more likely, we have
means determined by the Dean.
If our objective is to seek better methods of
education and in doing so, to determine
how we are to face the issues mentioned
above, I would hope that we choose a system
prososed by a committee of different
members from the community rather than
choose no system or a system by one isolated
administrator, Dean Benton.
Finally, the Goverance Report is rather
long and, in places, perhaps, difficult to
understand. The members of the committee,
I am sure, will be more than willing to
,discuss any part of this report or of the
background work that we have done.

By ED BRETHAUER
The Varsity Soccer Team played
its first scrimmage of this season
Tuesday, beating
Baltimore
University by a score of 4-3.
Neither team dominated the
game, although Hopkins held
Baltimore at bay till the last minutes
of the fourth quarter, while posting a
4-1 lead.
The Jays' offense, which scored 1
goal in each of the first two quarters
and two goals in the third, was led by
center Albee Samper.
Samper scored an unassisted goal
in the first quarter (five minutes into
the game), and livened up the
Hopkins offense by scoring in the
second quarter on a cross from
Scott Tyner.
Though the offensive line, consisting of Tyner, Samper, Manzio,
and Heller, seemed to produce most
of the excitement, the other unit of
Szeles, Barry, Waldt and Ross
seems to need only experience to
develop its passing and shooting.
Mediocre
The defense of Gavin Youngquist,
Jim Johnson and Paul Newlin,
which looked mediocre the first part
of the game, got tought in the second
quarter and held Baltimore to one
goal until the final minutes.
Youngquist demonstrated fine
leadership on the field at center
fullback, and was backed up ably by
Johnson who has a fine left foot kick.
Newlin, Tony, Bond and Harry
Furukawa all showed fine hustle and
spirit.
In the goal, Steve Buescher and
Steve Weiss combined to give up
only one score through 3 quarters of

play. Weiss looked particularly
impressive, bringing halfbacks Anay
Smith and Wes Daub back to help on
defense, positioning his fullbacks
perfectly, and making remarkable
saves.
His presence in the goal also
seemed to rally the Hopkins offense,
which scored twice more on Albee
Samper's third goal of the match,
and on halfback Ed Coza's first goal
of the season.
Tough Fullbacks
In the fourth quarter, Baltimore
tried to make the game close,
scoring twice off substitute goalie,
Bobby La Rosa. But the fullbacks
hung tough, and got enough help
from Smith, and Coza to close off
the rally and preserve the victory.
As several players have noted,
there is reason to be optimistic this
year, since the team has the needed
amount of experience, talent, depth
and spirit to produce a winning
season, barring any serious injuries.
If the defense can organize itself,
and if the offense can produce 1 or 2
goals a game, the team may even
take it all this season.

should get sick or quit, Hopkins would

The department is the key to the University, we will
learn today while sifting through pages of verbiage from
the summer governance committee. And just how do
Hopkins departments work? They debate substantive
conflicts in terms of procedure and mask their debates
in secrecy.
The most recent example occurred this week in the
Social Relations department. Unlike other courses
which are automatically approved by the chairman, the
department saw fit to review Dr. Chester Wickwire's
request to add two more courses to its paultry offerings
this semester. Meeting in privacy, without even the
courtesy to allow Dr. Wickwire to defend his program
(protocol restricts "part-time lecturers" from such
deliberations), they concluded the courses are inappropriate.
Wickwire was notified in writing of the decision
yesterday without explanation. When the News-Letter
tried to find out what had happened, the department
chairman refused to comment, saying he will only
answer written inquiries.
So an inkling of what happened to the courses has been
effectively stifled and with that, the 150 students who
expressed interest in the two rejected courses have been
cheated.
The main point, however, is not the numerous obstacles Wickwire has to face in order to develop practical courses in sociology. Rather it is the control
professors exercise, exclusively running "their"
departments without any attempt to garner junior
faculty or student opinion.

Defending Governance
By T. CHRISTOPHER BEACH.
The Summer Goverance Committee has
submitted to the Dean of the Faculty of Arts
and Sciences a report that recommends a
new system of governance for this division.
Copies of the report are now being printed
and within a few days will be returned and
distributed to all members of the division.
The committee's conception of how the
division has previously been governed is well
stated in the introductory chapter of the
report."An almost universal theme, running
alike through administration, faculty, and
students, was the perilously high level of
frustration over how and where to get things
done. Individual grievances and suggestions
have not been acted upon or even answered.
"Academic and nonacademic programs
and policies have emerged full grown, like
Botticelli's Venus, from the depths of administrative silence." That silence has
pervaded all levels of this division, from the
Student Council's administering of its affairs
to the "Administration's" administering of
everyone' affairs.
The committee did not seek, however, to
address its report to specific issues raised or
specific decisions made in the past two or
three years. Rather, the attempt was to
propose a new system that clearly defines
where an individual issue may be discussed
and where a decision made. '
The purpose of establishing such a
system is twofold: (1) to guarantee that an
individual's opinion on a specific subject
would be heard at a point where a decision
could be affected and (2) to guarantee that
the thought behind his opinion would be
answered, if not acted upon.
Right to Advise
In the report, the above guarantees are
termed "the right to advise" and the right to
hold accountable those who are advised." In
practice, the guarantees mean that before
an administrator makes a decision, he must
inform those groups to be affected by the
decision and seek either their advice or the
advice of a duly constituted body that
represents them. If such advance is refected
of modified at the time of the decision, the
administrator must explain his decision if
the advisory body, or group, so requests.
Because Woody Bennett and .Harry
Singleton, two of the undergraduate
members of the committee, have not signed
the majority report and have explained
themselves in two separate minority
reports. I would like to explain why I, the
third undergraduate, have endorsed the
recommendations of the majority report.
Flexible System
If put into effect, the recommended
system can be amended so that parts of it

with which I disagree can be reconsidered
and perhaps changed. If put into effect, the
recommended system will permit any individual or group of individuals who have
raised a controversial issue to know why
they have been accepted or rejected.
More specifically, if the Arts and Sciences
Representative Council is established, the
undergraduates, graduate students,
research staff and faculty will finally have a
chance to cooperate and, as a single group,
advise the Dean. Although some students
argue that advisory power is no power, I
can't agree. As stated in its constitution, the
Academic Council had only advisory
power; yet, the power -Mat our faculty
generates through its Council is as great as
the faculty power in any other university in
the country.
Department Guidelines
Further, the departmental guidelines that
have been recommended offer an even more
significant change in governance. If adopted
and followed, these guidelines offer the
student a much greater chance to determine
the course of his education. As, such the
guidelines are easily the most important
proposal.
At the present moment academic and nonacademic issues are pressing for resolution.
Already, controversy over the issues of APL
and ROTC has begun again. Already, Dean
Code of Conduct is being
Benton's
challenged. These and other issues require
extensive discussion and major dicisions of
policy. If the discussion is to be 'reasonable
and the decisions responsible, the proposed
system of governance should be accepted by
all members of the division.
Best Alternative
Our choice is either to accept or reject the
proposals. If we accept them, we know
what the means are for effecting' student
voice. If we reject them we have either no
means, or what is more likely, we have
means determined by the Dean.
If our objective is to seek better methods of
education and in doing so, to determine
how we are to face the issues mentioned
above, I would hope that we choose a system
prososed by a committee of different
members from the community rather than
choose no system or a system by one isolated
administrator, Dean Benton.
Finally, the Goverance Report is rather
long and, in places, perhaps, difficult to
understand. The members of the committee,
I am sure, will be more than willing to
,discuss any part of this report or of the
background work that we have done.

By ED BRETHAUER
The Varsity Soccer Team played
its first scrimmage of this season
Tuesday, beating
Baltimore
University by a score of 4-3.
Neither team dominated the
game, although Hopkins held
Baltimore at bay till the last minutes
of the fourth quarter, while posting a
4-1 lead.
The Jays' offense, which scored 1
goal in each of the first two quarters
and two goals in the third, was led by
center Albee Samper.
Samper scored an unassisted goal
in the first quarter (five minutes into
the game), and livened up the
Hopkins offense by scoring in the
second quarter on a cross from
Scott Tyner.
Though the offensive line, consisting of Tyner, Samper, Manzio,
and Heller, seemed to produce most
of the excitement, the other unit of
Szeles, Barry, Waldt and Ross
seems to need only experience to
develop its passing and shooting.
Mediocre
The defense of Gavin Youngquist,
Jim Johnson and Paul Newlin,
which looked mediocre the first part
of the game, got tought in the second
quarter and held Baltimore to one
goal until the final minutes.
Youngquist demonstrated fine
leadership on the field at center
fullback, and was backed up ably by
Johnson who has a fine left foot kick.
Newlin, Tony, Bond and Harry
Furukawa all showed fine hustle and
spirit.
In the goal, Steve Buescher and
Steve Weiss combined to give up
only one score through 3 quarters of

play. Weiss looked particularly
impressive, bringing halfbacks Anay
Smith and Wes Daub back to help on
defense, positioning his fullbacks
perfectly, and making remarkable
saves.

seemed to rally the Hopkins offense,
which scored twice more on Albee
Samper's third goal of the match,
and on halfback Ed Coza's first goal
of the season.
Tough Fullbacks

tried to make the game close,
scoring twice off substitute goalie,
Bobby La Rosa. But the fullbacks
hung tough, and got enough help
from Smith, and Coza to close off
the rally and preserve the victory.

there is reason to be optimistic this
year, since the team has the needed
amount of experience, talent, depth
and spirit to produce a winning
season, barring any serious injuries.
If the defense can organize itself,
and if the offense can produce 1 or 2
goals a game, the team may even
take it all this season.

processed through the school as if it were a factory."
